div1.head: Newspaper clipping, The New York Herald, Setember 2, 1901 [Enclosed in 06310070]
div1.p:
According to the unanimous opinion of
the Yellow Fever Board of Havana the ex-
periments of Drs. Caldas and Bellinzaghi
with their new vaccine and curative serum
have resulted in complete failure.

The trial was a fair one, and the result
was what might have been expected. The
HERALD several days ago ventured the opin-
ion that it was difficult to understand upon
what scientific basis the claims of these
gentlemen could rest, as no specific germ of
the fever had yet been satisfactorily demon-
strated. It now appears that the experi-
menters declined to exhibit their particular
microbe to the board. Certainly this seri-
ously prejudiced the case from an impartial
scientific standpoint, as did also the refusal
on the part of the inventors to divulge the
composition of their products. The army
board, however, very generously overlooked
such shortcomings and did its full duty as
an expert jury.

The experimenters in self-defence now
say that the case was not one of yellow
fever, and that the deductions of the board
are consequently unwarranted.

However this may be, it is high time to
call a halt in all such experiments. The
board has acted wisely in setting its face
against them in future. There are other
means of discovering curative measures
without ruthlessly risking human life.

It must by no means be inferred in spite
of occasional failures that careful investi-
gations on legitimate lines need to be discon-
tinued. Already very substantial progress
has been made in very promising directions.
The mosquito has within the last year
loomed up as a most important causative
factor in the problem. In fact, it would al-
most seem in the light of the recent obser-
vations that this insect is the main propa-
gating element of the disease. If this can
be proved beyond doubt by more extended
experience the matter of prevention can be
narrowed to very limited issues.

How to render persons immune to the dis-
ease is as yet far from being definitely set-
tled. Apparently the only hope of doing so
rests with the discovery of a protecting and
curative serum. The latter can be possible
only after the specific germ of the disease
is isolated and subjected to “control” ex-
periments. The model of such a find is the
antitoxin of diphtheria. Strange to say,
however, that agent is the only one of all
the alleged curative serums that has held
its own. Its discovery, however, proves an
important scientific principle, and similar
ones must necessarily follow in its wake.

The pity is at this juncture that Dr.
Caldas did not make good his claims and
give to the world the long wished for
remedy. But it must come ere long.

The earnest and bright workers in the
army laboratories are looking in right direc-
tions. When they succeed there will be
nothing hidden as to their methods of work-
ing, as to the composition of their mixtures
or their modes of manufacture. Thus, too,
will science have no secrets from humanity
and no pecuniary gains from human suffer-
ing.

Fortunately we can at this writing the
more patiently await developments in view
of the fact that fewer cases of the fever
exist than ever before, and that no time is
being lost in applying all those improved
methods of sanitation which, above all
theories, prove the safest of all methods of
public reform and the surest of all means of
future safety.
